nodes.text: Using taxes and public production as control variables, the government should choose policies to maximize social welfare and this optimization yields (under stated assumptions) aggregate production efficiency and a specific optimal tax structure
Aggregate production efficiency is desirable in a wide variety of circumstances even when lump sum taxes are unavailable

The optimal tax structure satisfies first-order conditions equating the marginal social benefit of a price change to the social marginal cost, leading (in the individualistic welfare case) to proportionality conditions between marginal tax revenue and quantities (Ramsey-type conditions)

Method: Reformulate the planner problem in terms of consumer prices q (indirect welfare V(q)), express production constraints G and equilibrium demands x(q), and solve via Lagrangian with producer prices p and public inputs z as auxiliary variables

Assumptions critical to results: constant returns and price-taking in private production (so zero profits), differentiability and continuity of demand, availability of commodity taxes (no lump sum), and standard convexity/closedness conditions for production and consumption sets

Many-consumer extension: indirect welfare V(q)=U(x1(q),...,xH(q)) can be used; production efficiency remains desirable under mild additional assumptions (continuity, possibility of a poll subsidy or availability of diverse commodity taxes)

Evidence/Theorem: From Lagrangian first-order condition for public inputs, equality of marginal rates of transformation between public and private production sectors holds (if Lagrange multiplier X not zero), implying aggregate production efficiency

Counterexamples and limitations: specific preference/technology configurations can give optima interior to the production set (not weakly efficient) - e.g., social preferences differing from individual ones or multi-household examples where optimal production is interior

Algebraic form of optimal tax conditions: Vk - X sum_i p_i (partial x_i / partial q_k) = 0 and, in the individualistic case, x_k = - (1/alpha) sum_i t_i (partial x_i / partial q_k), implying a constant ratio across commodities

Interpretation: the marginal utility change from a commodity price change must be proportional to the change in tax revenue evaluated at constant producer prices; tax administrator need not consider price responses in first-order conditions

Method detail: reduce controls to consumer prices q and public input vector z by using producer price determination from profit maximization and private production constraints, then maximize V(q) subject to aggregate feasibility X(q) in production set G

Theorems on existence and efficiency: under assumptions (continuity, convexity, closedness, nonempty bounded attainable set) an optimum exists (Theorem 1,2,3) and Lemma 1 provides conditions (nonzero derivative of V in some price) ensuring optimal production lies on the production frontier

Policy implication: when private production sectors are price-taking with constant returns, intermediate-good taxation is suboptimal because the same revenue can be raised by final-good taxes without producing production inefficiency

Extensions and robustness: results extend to cases with poll taxes/subsidies, untaxable sectors (treating some production as consumer sector), international trade (treat foreigners as additional consumer groups when reactions are well-defined), migration (use continuum of consumers), consumption externalities and some capital market imperfections alter optimal tax formulas but typically not the desirability of production efficiency

Limitation: if constraints bind on the relationship between producer prices and consumer demands (e.g., presence of pure profits, inability to tax certain transactions, or fixed producer-consumer price links), the efficiency conclusion may fail

Conclusion: given the model and assumptions the planner should implement aggregate production efficiency and set commodity taxes according to derived first-order conditions, while recognizing exceptions and the need to adjust formulas when assumptions fail
